doc.title: Why the liquidity-driven rally has further to go
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/China Musings Why the liquidity-driven rally has further to goChina Musings Why the liquidity-driven rally has further t_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: past 2 weeks, with A- share large and small caps surging \(8\%\) and \(10\%\) since August on record volumes, and H shares making new year- to- date/4- year highs in 2 out of the past 5 trading days. The rally has manifested against a backdrop where macro statistics are showing signs of cyclical softness and consensus profit revisions are muted, prompting investor questions about the durability of this liquidity- driven rally. We note that "liquidity" has boosted equity returns globally, and with (i) China equity multiples at mid- range levels, (ii) trend profit growth running at high- single- digit pace, (iii) A- share retail risk appetite only moderately above neutral territory on our measures, (iv) far- from- extended fund positioning across investor types, and (v) strong potential for asset reallocation flows to equities, we believe the uptrend has legs notwithstanding near- term profit taking pressures. Key risks are abrupt market liquidity tightening, regulation shocks, and macro policy disappointments, which have tended to derail most flow- powered equity booms historically. We stay overweight China Offshore and A shares in a regional context, forecast \(10\%\) \(12m\) returns for MSCI China (90) and \(12\%\) for CSI300 per our improved index target for the latter (4,900), but reiterate our alpha- over- beta bias to trade for better risk/reward.
Exhibit 1: The summer breakout has gathered steam for Chinese equities, with A shares leading the charge in recent weeks
Source: FactSet, MSCI, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

2. A slowing economy, but rising stock markets. Macro datapoints have exhibited signs of growth fatigue starting in July, after surprising investor expectations to the upside in the first half of the year, helped predominately by the resilient export market. Our economists expect that, with the full-year official growth target of around \(5\%\) more or less within reach, sequential growth slowdown is going to prevail in the remainder of 2025 considering the likely payback of front-loading exports and the lack of (and low urgency for) aggressive and large-scaled policy stimulus. In the listed universe, consensus earnings revision trends have stalled in recent months, consistent with the broadly pedestrian 2Q/1H earnings results so far in this reporting season. We keep our EPS growth of \(8 - 9\%\) for 2025, above sell-side consensus forecast of \(5\%\) for H shares but below that of \(15\%\) for A-shares.
Exhibit 2: Macro datapoints have shown early signs of cyclical moderation
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 3: Consensus earnings revision trends have been soft in recent months
Source:FactSet, MSCI, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

3. Policy has instilled optimism and reflated valuations. MSCI China and CSI300 have gained \(27\%\) and \(11\%\) ytd, mainly on multiples expansion. We ascribe the valuation recovery to a number of policy (related) events and positive catalysts that have materialized in the past year, namely the policy pivot in September last year that took out the left-tail risks in Chinese equities, the "DeepSeek Moment" in late January that has rewritten the AI/Tech narrative for China, the POE Symposium in February which suggested that the regulatory tightening towards the private economy is probably over, the de-escalation of US-China trade tensions since late April, and the CCFEA meeting in early July where President Xi called for more rational competition, and the anti-involution rhetoric has triggered a reflation trade in the financial markets. In our view, the common trait of these events is that they are helpful in compressing equity/policy risk premium and shoring up forward earnings expectations, although the immediate earnings impacts are likely limited.
Exhibit 4: Policy events have reflated China equity valuations in the past 2 years
Source:MSCI,FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 5: Valuation expansion has led the equity rally so far this year
Source:FactSet,IBES,MSCI,CSI,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Among the top- 10 equity markets across DM and EM (ex- China), which account for over \(90\%\) of total market capitalization globally, 8 are currently trading at or close to their all- time highs in local currency terms and are priced at the top- end of their respective valuation ranges. For comparison, China Offshore and A shares are \(34\%\) and \(26\%\) below their ATHs recorded in 2021. Furthermore, the divergence in performance between the real economy (proxied by GS CAI) and financial economy (based on local market equity returns) seems to be manifesting across major equity blocs around the world, with the macro- market correlations for China and the US falling to the lowest level since 2021 and 2020. This suggests that liquidity factors and valuation expansion, as opposed to cyclical macro fundamentals, have been the main propeller of equity gains globally, China included.
Exhibit 6: Many key equity markets globally are trading at or close to all-time highs
Note: Calculation based on MSCI market performance if not specified. LOC applied.
Exhibit 7: Chinese equities' returns have been less correlated with macro performance, so have many key equity markets globally
Source:FactSet,MSCI,Goldman Sachs Global Investment

5. The beauty of low (valuation) starting points. Despite the \(48\%\) index rebound from the cycle trough in late 2022, MSCI China is trading on \(12.6x\) and \(15.2x\) consensus 12m earnings in cap-weighted and stock-median terms, 0.3 and -0.4x s.d. vs. 10-year averages. In A shares, headline index PEs are slightly above mid-cycle (+1.2 s.d.), but equity risk premium (ERP) appears elevated vis-a-vis government bond pricing. While A-share small caps (CSI1000) are priced at comparatively high absolute valuations (23x,

0.7 s.d.) after printing \(23\%\) gains ytd, they are \(50\%\) below their historical PE peak in 2015. Importantly, China equities continue to trade on meaningful valuation discounts to their DM alternatives and largely on par with their EM peers, implying to us that investors are not over-paying for the upside liquidity optionality in China vs. the rest of the world. Our top- down macro PE model now suggests that MSCI China should trade at around \(12.5x\) (from \(12x\) that we previously assumed), benefiting mainly from the further re- rating in US equities, while the equilibrium index P/E for CSI300 could reach \(15.8x\) , accounting for the improving liquidity backdrop and positive sentiment shift there.
Exhibit 8: Chinese stocks are priced at mid-cycle valuations in both median stock PE and market ERP terms
Source:FactSet,Wind,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 9: China equities are trading at significant discounts to DM equities, while the gaps have narrowed vis- a-vis EMs
Source:FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 10: We estimate that A shares' equilibrium valuation could reach \(15.8x\) in a liquidity surge, risk-on regime
Source:Wind,FactSet,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

6. Which sentiment inning are we in for China A? The risk-on in A shares has dominated our client conversations of late. The trading stats and headlines are indeed eye-popping: Shanghai Composite is now at a 10-year high, retail margin financing

balance is approaching its 2015 peak of Rmb2.3tn, and cash turnover has surpassed Rmb2tn for 12- consecutive days, the longest in history. All these may paint a picture that onshore risk appetite is extended and speculation risk is rising, and therefore have drawn comparisons to previous boom- bust episodes. However, our A- share retail sentiment proxy, a comprehensive risk- appetite indicator which encompasses 11 distinct variables centering on flows, allocation, and speculative length, suggests that while investor sentiment has improved in recent weeks, it's nowhere near the euphoric levels observed in the 2015 leverage- fueled surge and the Sep 2024 policy- triggered upswing. If retail risk appetite were to return to the 2024 and 2015 peaks, CSI300 would trade at 5180 and 5870 respectively \((+18\%\) and \(+34\%\) vs current), assuming the sensitivity between our sentiment measure and index returns stays constant.
Exhibit 11: Onshore retail sentiment per our measure is far from its recent peak in October 2024
Source:Wind,CSF,SSE,SZSE,SIPF,ICBC,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 12: Our China A-share retail sentiment proxy comprises 11 inputs that span across 3 key categories

Inputs to China A-shares retail sentiment proxyVariablesUnitFrequencySinceSourceAverageStdevCurrent valuez-scoreSpeculative lengthMargin trading balanceRMB bnD2012CSF108851521322.0Margin buyingRMB bnD2012CSF63482614.1Margin buying to short selling ratioxD2012CSF1171081440.2ST limit up#D2012Wind67110.8Equity allocationSMD cap ETF flowsRMB bnD2023Wind0.23.22.30.7New equity MF shares issued# bnD2012Wind2.74.13.90.3New account opening# mnM2012SSE1.91.32.00.1TradingTotal turnoverRMB bnD2012Stock Exchanges69443624254.0Turnover velocityxD2012Stock Exchanges83121.5Small order as of total flows%W: D2015Wind4312450.1IPO day-1 performance%D2019Wind91100890.0

SIPF data is available during 2012-2017; IPO day-1 performance starts in 2019 when limit-up/down was removed for first 5 trading days; SDMA of the median of all z-scores is taken to calculate the retail sentiment proxy
Source: Wind, CSF, SSE, SZSE, SIPF, ICBC, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

7. Positioning is far from crowded across investor types. Chinese investors have been the main capital sponsors for this bull run, as evidenced by the record-breaking Southbound inflows into the HK market, the resurgent onshore retail sentiment and trading activity, and the downside put underwritten by the Chinese National Team in the post-Liberation Day drawdown. That said, onshore mutual funds have only begun to raise equity exposures in the past weeks, Chinese insurers' equity allocation is significantly trailing the statutory limits (30%), while hedge funds and active mandates

globally remain stubbornly underweight Chinese stocks relative to past ranges or benchmark weights, all pointing to potential for positioning and allocation upside down the road, and consistent with our recent global marketing feedback which points to a wide gap between rising foreign investor interest in Chinese stocks and their still- conservative equity allocations.
Exhibit 13: Chinese investors have been the main capital sponsors for the prevailing bull run
Source:Wind,EPFR,MSCI,Goldman Sachs Prime Services,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

8. Asset re-allocation flows are likely in motion. It's well documented that Chinese households are over-exposed to property but under-allocated to equities in a global context. We've written extensively on the potential for asset re-allocation flows in favor of equities, and we believe the necessary conditions for a major shift are gradually falling into place, notably: a) Rmb55tn of excess household savings accumulated in the post-Covid era of which a significant portion of time deposits could soon come due per media reports; b) an L-shaped recovery in the housing market that seems unlikely to be perceived by Chinese households as the key investment vehicle for wealth accumulation; c) a series of corporate and regulatory reforms (Nine Measures in particular) that have raised the investment appeal and realized returns of equities for individuals and long-duration asset managers relative to other competing asset classes; and d) the anti-involution campaign has helped strengthen reflation expectation in the financial markets, thereby lowering real yields and driving fund rotation from bonds to equities.
Exhibit 14: The potential for asset re-allocation flows to equities could be significant
Source:PBOC,Wind,CBRIC,SSF,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 15: Equities have become more attractive to Chinese households and long-duration asset managers from an asset allocation perspective

China offshore equities: MSCI China total returns; China onshore equities: CSI300 total returns; Global equity: MSCI ACWI total returns; China bond: ChinaBond New Composite Index total return; Property: 70-city price changes and rental yields; Deposit: 1-year deposit rate
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

9. What could go wrong? Historically, high equity multiples, on a standalone basis, seldom mark the turning point of major flow-driven equity booms, but it's rather policy shocks in the form of abrupt market liquidity tightening (i.e., the off-balance-sheet leverage curb in 2015), regulation changes (regulatory crackdown on property developers and POEs in 2021), and policy disappointments (e.g., post the Sep 24 policy pivot) that were responsible for reversing the bull runs. Given the increasing strategic importance of the stock market to the economy in terms of allocating resources, funding new productive growth drivers, and creating wealth and positive sentiment for Chinese households, we believe the likelihood of a policy-engineered equity downturn is low unless there is clearer evidence of valuation excess and rampant speculation emerges.
Exhibit 16: History suggests this rally may have more legs

Post GFC Recovery (Oct 2008 - Nov 2009)Leverage-Led A-Share Rally (Mar 2014 - Apr 2015)Covid Stimulus Package (Mar 2020 - Feb 2021)Reopening (Oct 2022 - Jan 2023)Policy Pivot &amp; DeepSeek (Sep 2024 - Mar 2025)Current (Aug 2025 - Now)
Exhibit 17: We would continue to focus on sector and thematic alpha opportunities to trade for better risk/reward
Source:FactSet,MSCi,Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 18: Our valuation model suggests a 12.5x fair P/E for MSCI China
